From the votes and comments, it looks like people like the problem. However, the approvals are not on schedule to make it. If you are lvl 20+, please take the time to either comment constructive feedback, or approve the puzzle. I think the feedback I've gotten has led to an improved puzzle.

Contrary to first impressions, the problem has an elegant solution, but it's not easy to find. My solution is 50 lines in python and does not contain many cases / hard-coding. If you want, you can look at the indented solution described in another comment.

My puzzle solution

SPOILER BELOW!

A cube configuration is made up of 54 stickers. Each twist of the Rubik's cube corresponds to applying a permutation to these stickers.

The tasks asks us to find the doubly solved configuration. If we find a permutation Given -> Solved, then applying it again we get Solved -> Answer. If the sticker colors were unique, finding the permutation would be trivial, but they are not.

The Rubik's cube is built of 3x3x3 smaller cubes called "cubies". Since they are solid, the set of stickers belonging to a each cubie never changes, and can hence be used to identify the cubie. It turns out each sticker can be uniquely identified by its color and cubie.

Putting this together:
1.
For each of the 54 stickers, assign it to a cubie by 3d coordinate. This can be done by 6 cases in a double for loop. Each cubie then has a set of colors identifying it.
2.
For each sticker, add the set of colors from its assigned cubie as its disambiguating context.
3.
Compute the above procedure for the given configuration and the solved configuration.
4.
Let's name the configurations Given, Solved and Answer, and use Given[A] for the color and context of the sticker at position A of Given. If Given[A] corresponds to Solved[B], then Solved[A] will correspond to Answer[B].
Nice, I like it

Comment:

I really like your puzzle. The description is quite good now. I think it is quite hard work to implement a correct program, but using group theory knowledge makes it much easier. It is not necessary to find the sequence of twists, only the list of piece movements.

I'm new to contributions, so someone please explain. It has been a few days, and there are no "approved" or "rejected". Is it the norm to wait until the last few days of validation before approving / rejecting? Or is the problem statement scaring people away, so they don't make an opinion? Or are moderators just scarce, in which case it might not get a verdict even after the 30 days?

I'd appreciate it if you could use the same color-agnostic code most of the other Rubik-related puzzles here follow.
See for example https://www.codingame.com/training/hard/cheat-solving

The way I read your statement, it feels more like a scramble inverter that a double solve, but that might not be so easy to explain in simple words.

I don't think this is a "hard" puzzle. It requires knowing the anatomy of a Rubik's cube, but the programming isn't too complicated. You just have to identify where the piece in each location belongs. The easiest solution would hardcode the locations of every cube's neighbors.

By the word "Doubly", I guess you are referring to a special sequence of turns on a cube, which may be well known among expert cube solvers but not to the general programmers.

Wish that the puzzle can be self-contained without needing coders to look outside to understand the details.
Wow, looking pretty good for a first contribution. Are you sure that there is only one unique answer per test? (I don't know, just asking).
This is my first contribution, so please tell me if something's wrong / non-standard.
Yes, I'm sure. It's easy to prove with the group theoretic view of the Rubik's cube.

From what I understand, you find the path to solve your cube, then if you apply that path to the solved cube you get back the starting configuration.
But I agree with you it's not super clear.
Actually, the fact that you change orientations (relative to the centers) makes orienting the solution much harder.

I didn't know there's a default way to describe cube states here, thank you for pointing that out. I will make the change. Is there an easier way to update the test cases than copying the output of my generator to 56 different text boxes?

You are correct that it's a scramble inverter, my original statement called it a cube inversion instead of doubly solved. However, I think this gives away part of the solution, and only helps those who already know about the group theoretic / mathy perspective. I'm updating the statement to try to make it clearer without mentioning inversions.

I had the same and my take on it is that solving your puzzle requires a fair amount of work, especially if you don't know group theory and have to handle all the rotations manually. Few people actually take the time to do it and so you receive little feedback.

That's my issue with your puzzle btw, I don't know the math stuff required to handle it properly so I'm expecting a painful coding time tbh. That doesn't mean it's a bad puzzle, just laborious.

Thank you for the approval, and congratulations on solving it!
Do you think it should have difficulty "very hard", or "hard" is appropriate?

I'd like to start by thanking you for such an excellent contribution; easily my favorite of every single one on the site! I think it would certainly constitute "very hard" if it involved implementing a complete solver, but of course there's a clever trick, so I think "hard" is the right choice.

That said, I was so excited to finally get mine working so I could see how a few other people approached it, but apparently I'm first? Would you mind publishing your solution at some point?

Either way, thanks again for a great puzzle. I had a blast solving it.

I'm glad you like it :)

I thought you would be able to see the solution when you solved it, because I needed to add an intended solution to submit the puzzle in the first place. As it seems this is not the case, I submitted it in the practice section. However, it seems I can't see your solution since my solution is python 3, and yours is Ruby, so probably you can't see mine. Where do you suggest I publish the solution?

Hm... submitting it in the practice section is what I did, but I think you also have to explicitly hit the "Publish to CodinGame" button for others solvers to be able to see it. It should then show up on https://www.codingame.com/training/hard/doubly-solved-rubiks-cube/solution.

I pressed "Publish to CodinGame" now, but I guess you need to solve it in python to see the solution. I don't see any other reason why I wouldn't be able to see your solution than the languages being different.

I feel like people are scared by fancy words such as "group theory", and anatomy of the Rubik's cube. However, the "group theory" is basically just that we can represent a cube configuration (or sequence of moves) by a permutation of stickers. And the "anatomy" is that the cube is built of 3x3x3 "cubies" which can be uniquely identified by their stickers. My solution is 50 lines using only these facts, and it's fairly straightforward.

Do you think it's a good idea to give part of the solution / hints / the full solution in the comments? Would that solve the intimidation problem?

It would certainly be nice if written in a teaching fashion, or maybe have a link to a good explanation. Because imagine you didn't know anything about your current method, how would you solve the puzzle ? :-)

I added a description of my solution.

If I knew nothing about my current method, I think I would just reinvent it, since that's what I did when I first made the puzzle, and I see no reason this time would be different.

If you are asking how I would approach / solve the puzzle if I didn't know anything about the Rubik's cube, it's hard to imagine. However, I think I would spend some time to figure out the needed insights, but end up with a similar solution to what I have now.

For someone who doesn't know anything about solving a rubik's cube I think the most natural approach is to create a 3x3 matrix for each face, then functions for each possible move with mappings from face to face. Which is very prone to bugs and frustration.

I don't see the description you're mentioning, do you mean the comments in your solution ?

I agree the most natural / first approaches would be involving lots of cases. However, that would be hard to implement correctly, and therefore I would look for simpler solutions / simplifications before attempting to implement anything. That's where I think I would find insights such as the permutation view, and how to identify stickers without hard-coding all 20 pieces.

The description is currently the latest comment on the problem (top level), at the very top.
Done! Now I use the same format as the link you sent.

I agree understanding "what we want to do" is easy if you know the group theoretic view of the Rubik's cube. However, I think implementing it is harder than "medium", as hard-coding each piece requires something like 20 cases (which gives lots of room for bugs) and is non-trivial because of piece orientations. 
If you implemented it, and have an easier solution than my given python solution (which I think is pretty nice, but not intuitive to come up with), I'm interested to hear it.

You don't get back to the starting configuration.
In the example, "solving" the cube consists of rotating the red side 90 degrees clockwise. If you apply that rotation again to the solved cube, you have in total rotated the red side 180 degree.

So the output we give is the cube you would you get by applying to a solved cube the sequence that let you solve the cube from your starting configuration in the first place.
In any case you should consider explaining it further, we wouldn't need to discuss this if the description was clear.

The answer is the same for any sequence of moves you used to solve the given cube. However, this was not clear in the original statement, so I update it. Is it clearer now?

The puzzle is supposed to be solvable without any expert knowledge of the Rubik's cube.
Yes it's better now, the description makes more sense.
